description: From late Middle English comporten, from Old French comporter, from Latin comportare (“to bring together”), from com- (“together”) + portare (“to carry”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Manner of acting; conduct; comportment; deportment.

verbs.description: comport (third-person singular simple present comports, present participle comporting, simple past and past participle comported)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive, intransitive) To tolerate, bear, put up (with). [16th–19th c.]
(intransitive) To be in agreement (with); to be of an accord. [from 16th c.]
examples: The new rules did not seem to comport with the spirit of the club.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To behave (in a given manner). [from 17th c.]
